Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: A sexton accidentally locks a hog in the church. He hears a noise & alerts the clergyman, who puts on his vestments, takes the Bible, & asks the sexton to open the church door. The hog runs between the clergyman’s legs & hurries away with him riding on his back. The clergyman thinks he is being taken away by the devil.

Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: A church officer wants to make some farm-ers (a woman) come to church more often. He scatters millet outside the church & treads it down after it sprouts. Then he accuses the farmers of having dropped it. They reply that it could not have been they, because they have not been to the church for a long time.

Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: This misc. type consists of various anecdotes about drunk-en ness & card playing in church. In many variants a clergyman falls asleep in the church. When he wakes up (is awakened by the sexton), he thinks he is at an inn. He declares which cards are trumps or orders another drink.

Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: A card-playing clergyman makes a bet that he will be able to call out a trump suit during his next sermon. In his sermon, he declares that a certain card is trump but adds that God is a better trump than any card.

Classifications: At the Blessing of the Grave, the Clergyman's Ox Breaks Loose
Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: While officiating at a burial (church service), the clergyman observes that his ox has broken its tether. He curses it (says it is possessed by the devil), & the congregation thinks he is cursing the dead man.

Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: A clergyman steals something but promises to pray for the man from whom it was stolen. However, he accuses the man who was stolen from, & absolves the man who stole.

Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: A clergyman asks a boy how his family says grace. The boy does not understand, so the clergyman asks what his father says before they eat. The boy answers, “Come here, children!” (“Come & get it, lions!”)

Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: The owner of a faithful dog (donkey, goat, hog) wants the animal to be buried in the churchyard with a proper burial service. The clergyman refuses. After the owner explains that the animal left a large legacy to the church, the clergyman changes his mind. The clergyman (animal’s owner) has to answer to the bishop because he has buried the animal. He offers him some of the money from the supposed legacy & the bishop overcomes his objection to the burial.

Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: This misc. type consists of various anecdotes in which an avaricious clergyman tries to get money but is outwitted.

Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: A clergyman (rector) invites an acquaintance to dinner & shows him his house. The guest takes a silver spoon & hides it in the clergyman’s (cook’s) bed. Some time later the clergyman asks his guest about the spoon, which has been missing since this visit. The acquaintance answers that if the clergyman had slept in his own bed during this time, he would have found the spoon.

Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: This misc. type consists of various anecdotes in which a clergyman goes to someone’s deathbed, with absurd results.

Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: A clergyman intends to pay a visit to a man whose wife has recently died, but he comes to the wrong house where a man lives whose bicycle has been stolen. The clergyman expresses his condolences, & the man answers, “She was not worth much – she kept creaking & groaning whenever I was on her (was only good for yokels to ride)”.

Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: This misc. type consists of various anecdotes, e.g. a clergyman eats beside someone’s sickbed (deathbed). The sick person hears him & complains, “How he gnaws away!” The clergyman answers, “Yes, illness is like that”.

Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: A student comes to a village & promises to cure a calf (donkey) that belongs to an old woman (to cure the old woman herself). He writes, “If he does not live, let him die”, on a piece of paper which he puts in a bag & tells her to hang it around the animal’s neck. The calf recovers. Some time later, the student comes again to the village as a clergyman (teacher). He becomes ill, & the villagers recommend an old woman who is known for her ability to cure the sick. She gives him a little bag to hang around his neck. Inside the bag he finds his own message, & he laughs so hard that he recovers.

Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: A man (Jew, robber, farmer) praises a sermon on the theme [Matthew 7,2], “If someone strikes you on the right cheek, turn the other cheek to him also”. He gives the clergyman a blow on the ear to see if he will act as the Bible recommends. Instead, the clergyman hits him back, quoting [Matthew 5,39], “With the measure you use, it will be measured to you, & even more”. In some variants there are witnesses to the fight who say that both men are interpreting the Bible. Or, the fight is between a gentleman & a clergyman. The gentle -man hits the clergyman with a stick, saying, “This is Moses’ staff, with which he drew water out of the rock”. The clergyman draws a pistol & says, “This is Aaron’s holy censer”.

Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: A farmer (boy) who comes to confession cannot remember how many times he sinned. The clergyman tells him that every time he sins, he should put a pebble (potato) aside. The next time he comes to confession, the man brings two large sacks of pebbles (a wheelbarrow load of potatoes).

Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: A clergyman (Nasreddin Hodja) who cannot read the calendar puts beans (peas, grains of corn, pumpkin seeds) into his jacket pocket cor responding to the number of days in Lent (Ramadan). Each day he removes (eats) one bean (throws it in a pot). His wife (daughter) finds the beans and, thinking her husband likes them to eat, adds another handful. When the clergyman is asked how many more fast days there are, he counts the beans in his pocket & names an absurdly big number (says that Easter will not come this year; or, he finds colored eggshells & says that Easter is here already). Or, a clergyman makes a broom (wheel; collects a single egg) each day of the week so that he will know when Sunday comes. When he has six brooms, he tells the sexton to ring the bells on the follow-ing day. A neighbor (sexton) notices this scheme & hides one of the brooms, so that the clergyman makes a mistake & misses the service on Sunday.

Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: A clergyman who cannot read forgets to announce the holy days to his congregation. He hears that it is already Palm Sunday. When he goes back to his congregation, he tells them that Lent was shortened to one week this year because of the hard winter & that Easter will come next week. Or, an illiterate clergyman forgets or mixes up others of the holy days of the church calendar.

Classifications: The Clergyman on the Cow's Tail
Subcategory: 1800-1849 Other Clergyman Jokes
Variation Example: A clergyman (organist) has a cow that swishes her tail to shoo away flies when she is being milked. In order to stop this, the clergyman ties her tail to his jacket (around his neck). When a wasp stings the cow, she runs away, dragging the clergyman after her. In some variants from southeast Europe, a clergyman sits on the back of an unruly cow while his wife (farmhand) milks it. The cow runs away with the clergyman. Others ask him where he is going, & he replies, “Only God & this stupid cow know!”.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: This misc. type consists of various anecdotes that make fun of the extreme credulity of devout old women.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: This misc. type consists of various anecdotes about millers, especially in which they steal from their customers.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: This misc. type consists of various anecdotes about Jews. Most are anti-Semitic.

Classifications: Jewish Woman Makes Parents Believe that She is to Give Birth to the Messiah
Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: A young Jewish woman (nun) becomes pregnant by a student (clergyman). Out of fear of her father, the student disguises himself as an angel & tells the father that his daughter will give birth to the Messiah. Many people come to witness the birth. The woman bears a daughter (whom her angry father kills).

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: On his deathbed, a Jew (farmer) asks his sons how much money they will put in his coffin to be buried with him. After he dies, two of the sons put the promised money into the coffin. The third writes a check for the entire amount. He puts this in the coffin & takes out the money that his brothers had put there for himself.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: A Jew falls into a well (canal) but refuses to be pulled out, because it is the Sabbath. On the following day (Sunday) he calls for help, but now his Christian rescuer refuses because of his own Sabbath.

Classifications: You Don't Know What You are Missing
Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: A priest rides in a train eating a ham sandwich. He offers one to a rabbi (Jew) sitting across from him. The rabbi explains that he is not allowed to eat pork. The clergyman says, “You don’t know what you are missing – pork is very good”. When the clergyman leaves the train, the rabbi says, “Greetings to your wife”. The clergyman answers that he is not allowed to marry. The rabbi replies, “You don’t know what you are missing – women are very good”.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: A rabbi asks two clergymen of different religions how much of the collection money they keep for themselves. One keeps five percent, & the other, ten percent. They ask him the same question, & he answers, “I throw it all into the air & whatever those above do not take, I keep for myself”.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: A painter paints beautiful children, although his own children are ugly. Someone asks him why this is, & he explains that he makes the first by day & the second by night.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: In order to atone for his sins, or because someone has asked him to, a man (nobleman, Eulenspiegel, woman) under takes to paint a picture of the children of Israel crossing the Red Sea. He covers the canvas (wall) entirely with red. When asked where the children of Israel & the Egyptians are, the painter answers that the Israelites have already passed through, & the Egyptians havedrowned.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: This misc. type consists of various anecdotes about (usually) clever lawyers.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A man tells a magistrate (mayor, lawyer, policemen) that he dreamed about (went to) hell. There, in the fire, he was about to sit on an empty chair, but one of the devils stopped him, saying that it was reserved for the magistrate. (2) A man (St. Peter, several saints) in heaven wants to have a trial to establish his rights, but there are no lawyers there to conduct it.

Classifications: Dying Like Christ - Between Two Thieves
Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: A dying man asks his wife to summon the lawyer & the notary (clergyman & sexton). When they stand on both sides of his deathbed, he says that he feels like the dying Christ, between two thieves.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: A defense lawyer speaks so eloquently that his client, who had confessed to a crime, comes to doubt his own guilt & changes his plea.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: Two farmers (neighbors) have an argument (over their common boundary) & go to court to settle their dispute. They go one after the other to the same lawyer, who refers the second man to a colleague, giving him a letter. The farmer opens the letter & sees that the lawyer promises his colleague & himself a good profit. The farmer shows the letter to the other farmer, & they settle their dispute without legal help.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: A farmer has received a legal statement from a lawyer. When checking the document, for which he has to pay by the page, he realizes that the lawyer has written the paper with wide spaces between the lines (and that the last part of the page is blank). The lawyer explains that this is how documents have to be written. The farmer cannot pay the bill & offers to repay the lawyer with his own work. He takes revenge by threshing the lawyer’s grain (plowing his field), leaving wide spaces unthreshed between the rows. He explains that this is called “document-style threshing”.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: This misc. type comprises various anecdotes about judges, in most of which the judge settles a case to his own disadvantage.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: A proud woman (mayor’s wife, male student) arrives late in church (appears before an academic assembly) just as the congregation (audience) is standing up to pray. She thinks they have stood up on her account, so she bids them sit down (the student says he will take the seat by the door). She too had once been poor.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: In order to resolve their dispute, two men go to a judge. Before the judge makes his decision, one of the men brings him a wagon (ox, ax, jar of oil, milk, brass lamp). The other man brings him a horse (fur, cow or butter, sow, piglet, mule). The judge decides in favor of the second man. When the first man complains that his wagon went the wrong way, the judge explains that it went the way the horse pulled it. (the fur stopped up the ox’s throat, the sow knocked over the oil jar, the piglet drank the milk, etc.)

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: This misc. type consists of various anecdotes about doctors. In many cases, the doctor does not know how to treat a patient (and the patient dies). In others, the patient takes the doctor’s instructions literally or follows them incorrectly.

Classifications: Sham Phsyician: Using the Flea Powder
Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: A huckster sells powder that he guarantees will kill fleas. When someone asks how to use it, he replies that one has to catch the flea, hold its mouth open, & put a grain of powder in it.
